Suez Canal  
---

EO.JPG/280px-SuezCanal-EO.JPG)](/wiki/File:SuezCanal-EO.JPG)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Iss016e019375.jpg/220px-
Iss016e019375.jpg)](/wiki/File:Iss016e019375.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Iss016e019375.jpg "Enlarge")

The southern terminus of the Suez Canal at Suez on the Gulf of Suez (Red Sea)

The **Suez Canal** ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): قناة
السويس‎ __qanāt as-suwēs__) is an artificial [sea-level](/wiki/Sea-level "Sea-
level") [waterway](/wiki/Waterway "Waterway") in [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"),
connecting the [Mediterranean Sea](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean
Sea") to the [Red Sea](/wiki/Red_Sea "Red Sea") through the [Isthmus of
Suez](/wiki/Isthmus_of_Suez "Isthmus of Suez"). Constructed by the [Suez Canal
Company](/wiki/Suez_Canal_Company "Suez Canal Company") between 1859 and 1869,
it was officially opened on 17 November 1869. The [canal](/wiki/Canal "Canal")
offers [watercraft](/wiki/Watercraft "Watercraft") a shorter journey between
the [North Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean#NORTH_ATLANTIC "Atlantic Ocean") and
northern [Indian Oceans](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") via the
[Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea") and [Red
Seas](/wiki/Red_Sea "Red Sea") by avoiding the South Atlantic and southern
Indian Oceans, reducing the journey by approximately 7,000 kilometres (4,300
mi). It extends from the northern terminus of [Port Said](/wiki/Port_Said
"Port Said") to the southern terminus of [Port Tewfik](/wiki/Port_Tewfik "Port
Tewfik") at the city of [Suez](/wiki/Suez "Suez"). Its length is 193.30 km
(120.11 mi), including its northern and southern access channels. In 2012,
17,225 vessels traversed the canal (average 47 per day).[1]

The original canal was a single-lane waterway with passing locations in the
Ballah Bypass and the [Great Bitter Lake](/wiki/Great_Bitter_Lake "Great
Bitter Lake").[2] It contains no [locks](/wiki/Lock_\(water_transport\) "Lock
\(water transport\)") system, with seawater flowing freely through it. In
general, the canal north of the Bitter Lakes flows north in winter and south
in summer. South of the lakes, the current changes with the [tide](/wiki/Tide
"Tide") at Suez.[3]

The canal is owned and maintained by the [Suez Canal
Authority](/wiki/Suez_Canal_Authority "Suez Canal Authority")[4] (SCA) of
Egypt. Under the [Convention of
Constantinople](/wiki/Convention_of_Constantinople "Convention of
Constantinople"), it may be used "in time of war as in time of peace, by every
vessel of commerce or of war, without distinction of flag".[5]

In August 2014, construction was launched to expand and widen the Ballah
Bypass for 35 km (22 mi) to speed the canal's transit time. The expansion was
planned to double the capacity of the Suez Canal from 49 to 97 ships a day.[6]
At a cost of [$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")8.4
billion, this project was funded with [interest-bearing investment
certificates](/wiki/Sukuk "Sukuk") issued exclusively to Egyptian entities and
individuals. The "[New Suez Canal](/wiki/New_Suez_Canal "New Suez Canal")", as
the expansion was dubbed, was opened with great fanfare in a ceremony on 6
August 2015.[7]

On 24 February 2016, the Suez Canal Authority officially opened the new side
channel. This side channel, located at the northern side of the east extension
of the Suez Canal, serves the East Terminal for berthing and unberthing
vessels from the terminal. As the East Container Terminal is located on the
Canal itself, before the construction of the new side channel it was not
possible to berth or unberth vessels at the terminal while the convoy was
running.[8]

## Precursors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Precursors")]

Main article: [Canal of the Pharaohs](/wiki/Canal_of_the_Pharaohs "Canal of
the Pharaohs")

Ancient west–east canals were built to facilitate travel from the
[Nile](/wiki/Nile "Nile") River to the [Red Sea](/wiki/Red_Sea "Red
Sea").[9][10][11] One smaller canal is believed to have been constructed under
the auspices of [Senusret II](/wiki/Senusret_II "Senusret II")[12] or
[Ramesses II](/wiki/Ramesses_II "Ramesses II").[9][10][11] Another canal,
probably incorporating a portion of the first,[9][10] was constructed under
the reign of [Necho II](/wiki/Necho_II "Necho II"), but the only fully
functional canal was engineered and completed by [Darius I](/wiki/Darius_I
"Darius I").[9][10][11]

### 2nd millennium
BCE[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section:
2nd millennium BCE")]

The legendary [Sesostris](/wiki/Sesostris "Sesostris") (likely either
[Pharaoh](/wiki/Pharaoh "Pharaoh") Senusret II or [Senusret
III](/wiki/Senusret_III "Senusret III") of the [Twelfth dynasty of
Egypt](/wiki/Twelfth_dynasty_of_Egypt "Twelfth dynasty of Egypt")[12][13]) may
have started work on an ancient canal joining the Nile with the Red Sea (1897
BC – 1839 BC), when an irrigation channel was constructed around 1850 BC that
was navigable during the flood season, leading into a dry river valley east of
the Nile River Delta named Wadi Tumelat.[14] (It is said that in [ancient
times](/wiki/Ancient_history "Ancient history") the Red Sea reached northward
to the [Bitter Lakes](/wiki/Bitter_Lakes "Bitter Lakes")[9][10] and [Lake
Timsah](/wiki/Lake_Timsah "Lake Timsah").[15][16])

In his _[Meteorology](/wiki/Meteorology_\(Aristotle\) "Meteorology
\(Aristotle\)")_ , [Aristotle](/wiki/Aristotle "Aristotle") wrote:

> One of their kings tried to make a canal to it (for it would have been of no
> little advantage to them for the whole region to have become navigable;
> Sesostris is said to have been the first of the ancient kings to try), but
> he found that the sea was higher than the land. So he first, and
> [Darius](/wiki/Darius_the_Great "Darius the Great") afterwards, stopped
> making the canal, lest the sea should mix with the river water and spoil
> it.[17]

[Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo") wrote that Sesostris started to build a canal,
and [Pliny the Elder](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny the Elder") wrote:

> 165\. Next comes the [Tyro](/wiki/Tyro "Tyro") tribe and, the harbour of the
> [Daneoi](/wiki/Daneoi "Daneoi"), from which Sesostris, king of Egypt,
> intended to carry a ship-canal to where the Nile flows into what is known as
> [the Delta](/wiki/Nile_Delta "Nile Delta"); this is a distance of over 60
> miles. Later the Persian king Darius had the same idea, and yet again
> [Ptolemy II](/wiki/Ptolemy_II "Ptolemy II"), who made a trench 100 feet
> wide, 30 feet deep and about 35 miles long, as far as the Bitter Lakes.[18]

In the second half of the 19th century, French
[cartographers](/wiki/Cartographer "Cartographer") discovered the remnants of
an ancient north–south canal past the east side of [Lake
Timsah](/wiki/Lake_Timsah "Lake Timsah") and ending near the north end of the
Great Bitter Lake.[19] This proved to be the celebrated canal made by the
Persian king [Darius I](/wiki/Darius_I "Darius I"), as his [stele](/wiki/Stele
"Stele") commemorating its construction was found at the site. (This ancient,
second canal may have followed a course along the shoreline of the Red Sea
when it once extended north to Lake Timsah.[16][19]) In the 20th century the
northward extension of this ancient canal was discovered, extending from Lake
Timsah to the [Ballah
Lakes](/w/index.php?title=Ballah_Lakes&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ballah Lakes
\(page does not exist\)").[20] This was dated to the [Middle Kingdom of
Egypt](/wiki/Middle_Kingdom_of_Egypt "Middle Kingdom of Egypt") by
extrapolating the dates of ancient sites along its course.[20]

The reliefs of the [Punt](/wiki/Land_of_Punt "Land of Punt") expedition under
[Hatshepsut](/wiki/Hatshepsut "Hatshepsut"), 1470 BC, depict seagoing vessels
carrying the expeditionary force returning from Punt. This suggests that a
navigable link existed between the Red Sea and the Nile.[21] Recent
[excavations in Wadi Gawasis](/wiki/Wadi_Gawasis "Wadi Gawasis") may indicate
that Egypt's maritime trade started from the Red Sea and did not require a
canal.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Evidence seems to indicate its existence by the 13th century BC
during the time of [Ramesses II](/wiki/Ramesses_II "Ramesses
II").[9][22][23][24]

### Canals dug by Necho, Darius I and
Ptolemy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Canals dug by Necho, Darius I and Ptolemy")]

Remnants of an ancient west–east canal through the [ancient
Egyptian](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt") cities of
[Bubastis](/wiki/Bubastis "Bubastis"), [Pi-Ramesses](/wiki/Avaris "Avaris"),
and [Pithom](/wiki/Pithom "Pithom") were discovered by [Napoleon
Bonaparte](/wiki/Napoleon_Bonaparte "Napoleon Bonaparte") and his engineers
and cartographers in 1799.[10][25][26][27][28]

According to the _[Histories](/wiki/The_Histories_of_Herodotus "The Histories
of Herodotus")_ of the [Greek](/wiki/Greeks "Greeks") historian
[Herodotus](/wiki/Herodotus "Herodotus"),[29] about 600 BC, [Necho
II](/wiki/Necho_II "Necho II") undertook to dig a west–east canal through the
Wadi Tumilat between Bubastis and [Heroopolis](/wiki/Pithom "Pithom"),[10] and
perhaps continued it to the [Heroopolite Gulf](/wiki/Heroopolite_Gulf
"Heroopolite Gulf") and the Red Sea.[9] Regardless, Necho is reported as
having never completed his project.[9][10]

Herodotus was told that 120,000 men perished in this undertaking, but this
figure is doubtless exaggerated.[30] According to [Pliny the
Elder](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny the Elder"), Necho's extension to the
canal was about 57 English miles,[10] equal to the total distance between
Bubastis and the Great Bitter Lake, allowing for winding through
[valleys](/wiki/Valley "Valley").[10] The length that Herodotus tells, of over
1000 [stadia](/wiki/Stadia_\(length\) "Stadia \(length\)") (i.e., over 114
miles (183 km)), must be understood to include the entire distance between the
Nile and the Red Sea[10] at that time.

With Necho's death, work was discontinued. Herodotus tells that the reason the
project was abandoned was because of a warning received from an
[oracle](/wiki/Oracle "Oracle") that others would benefit from its successful
completion.[10][31] Necho's war with [Nebuchadnezzar
II](/wiki/Nebuchadnezzar_II "Nebuchadnezzar II") most probably prevented the
canal's continuation.

Necho's project was completed by [Darius I of Persia](/wiki/Darius_I_of_Persia
"Darius I of Persia"), who ruled over [Ancient Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt
"Ancient Egypt") after it had been conquered by his predecessor [Cambyses
II](/wiki/Cambyses_II "Cambyses II").[32] It may be that by Darius's time a
natural[10] waterway passage which had existed[9] between the Heroopolite Gulf
and the Red Sea[33] in the vicinity of the Egyptian town of Shaluf[10] (alt.
_Chalouf_[34] or _Shaloof_[16]), located just south of the Great Bitter
Lake,[10][16] had become so blocked[9] with [silt](/wiki/Silt "Silt")[10] that
Darius needed to clear it out so as to allow [navigation](/wiki/Navigation
"Navigation")[10] once again. According to Herodotus, Darius's canal was wide
enough that two [triremes](/wiki/Trireme "Trireme") could pass each other with
oars extended, and required four days to traverse. Darius commemorated his
achievement with a number of [granite](/wiki/Granite "Granite")
[stelae](/wiki/Stela "Stela") that he set up on the Nile bank, including one
near Kabret, and a further one a few miles north of [Suez](/wiki/Suez "Suez").
The [Darius Inscriptions](/wiki/Darius_the_Great%27s_Suez_Inscriptions "Darius
the Great's Suez Inscriptions") read:[35]

> Saith King Darius: I am a Persian. Setting out from Persia, I conquered
> Egypt. I ordered this canal dug from the river called the Nile that flows in
> Egypt, to [the sea that begins in Persia](/wiki/Persian_Gulf "Persian
> Gulf"). When the canal had been dug as I ordered, ships went from Egypt
> through this canal to Persia, even as I intended.
>
> — Darius Inscription

The canal left the Nile at Bubastis. An inscription[36] on a pillar at
[Pithom](/wiki/Pithom "Pithom") records that in 270 or 269 BC, it was again
reopened, by [Ptolemy II Philadelphus](/wiki/Ptolemy_II_Philadelphus "Ptolemy
II Philadelphus"). In [Arsinoe](/wiki/Arsinoe_\(Gulf_of_Suez\) "Arsinoe \(Gulf
of Suez\)"),[10] Ptolemy constructed a [navigable
lock](/wiki/Lock_\(water_transport\) "Lock \(water transport\)"), with
[sluices](/wiki/Sluice "Sluice"), at the Heroopolite Gulf of the Red Sea,[33]
which allowed the passage of vessels but prevented salt water from the Red Sea
from mingling with the fresh water in the canal.[37]

### Receding Red Sea and the dwindling
Nile[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section:
Receding Red Sea and the dwindling Nile")]

The Red Sea is believed by some historians to have gradually receded over the
centuries, its coastline slowly moving southward away from [Lake
Timsah](/wiki/Lake_Timsah "Lake Timsah")[15][16] and the Great Bitter
Lake.[9][10] Coupled with persistent accumulations of Nile [silt](/wiki/Silt
"Silt"), maintenance and repair of Ptolemy's canal became increasingly
cumbersome over each passing century.

Two hundred years after the construction of Ptolemy's canal,
[Cleopatra](/wiki/Cleopatra_VII "Cleopatra VII") seems to have had no
west–east waterway passage,[9][10] because the [Pelusiac
branch](/wiki/Pelusiac_branch "Pelusiac branch") of the Nile, which fed
Ptolemy's west–east canal, had by that time dwindled, being choked with
silt.[9][10]

### Old Cairo to the Red
Sea[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section:
Old Cairo to the Red Sea")]

By the 8th century, a navigable canal existed between [Old
Cairo](/wiki/Old_Cairo "Old Cairo") and the Red Sea,[9][10] but accounts vary
as to who ordered its construction—either [Trajan](/wiki/Trajan "Trajan") or
['Amr ibn al-'As](/wiki/%27Amr_ibn_al-%27As "'Amr ibn al-'As"), or [Omar the
Great](/wiki/Umar "Umar").[9][10] This canal was reportedly linked to the
River Nile at Old Cairo[10] and ended near modern [Suez](/wiki/Suez
"Suez").[9][38] A geography [treatise](/wiki/Treatise "Treatise") by Dicuil
reports a conversation with an English monk, Fidelis, who had sailed on the
canal from the Nile to the Red Sea during a pilgrimage to the Holy Land in the
first half of the 8th century[39]

The [Abbasid](/wiki/Abbasid "Abbasid") [Caliph](/wiki/Caliph "Caliph") [al-
Mansur](/wiki/Al-Mansur "Al-Mansur") is said to have ordered this canal closed
in 767 to prevent supplies from reaching [Arabian](/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula
"Arabian Peninsula") detractors.[9][10]

### Repair by al-
Ḥākim[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Repair by al-Ḥākim")]

[Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah](/wiki/Al-Hakim_bi-Amr_Allah "Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah")
is claimed to have repaired the Cairo to Red Sea passageway,[9][10] but only
briefly, circa 1000 AD,[9][10] as it soon "became choked with sand."[10]
However, we are told that parts of this canal still continued to fill in
during the Nile's annual inundations.[9][10]

### Conception by
Venice[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Conception by Venice")]

The successful 1488 navigation of southern Africa by [Bartolomeu
Dias](/wiki/Bartolomeu_Dias "Bartolomeu Dias") opened a direct maritime
[trading route to India](/wiki/Trading_route_to_India "Trading route to
India") and the spice islands, and forever changed the balance of
Mediterranean trade. One of the most prominent losers in the new order, as
former middlemen, was the former spice trading center of [Venice](/wiki/Venice
"Venice").

> Venetian leaders, driven to desperation, contemplated digging a waterway
> between the Red Sea and the Nile—anticipating the Suez Canal by almost 400
> years—to bring the luxury trade flooding to their doors again. But this
> remained a dream.
>
> — Colin Thubron, _Seafarers: The Venetians_ (1980), p. 102

Despite entering negotiations with Egypt's ruling Mamelukes, the
[Venetian](/wiki/Republic_of_Venice "Republic of Venice") plan to build the
canal was quickly put to rest by the [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman
Empire") [conquest of Egypt in
1517](/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Mamluk_War_\(1516%E2%80%9317\) "Ottoman–Mamluk War
\(1516–17\)"), led by Sultan [Selim I](/wiki/Selim_I "Selim I")[40]

### Napoleon's discovery of an ancient
canal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Napoleon's discovery of an ancient canal")]

During the [French campaign in Egypt and
Syria](/wiki/French_campaign_in_Egypt_and_Syria "French campaign in Egypt and
Syria") in late 1798, [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon "Napoleon") showed an interest
in finding the remnants of an ancient waterway passage. This culminated in a
cadre of [archaeologists](/wiki/Archaeologist "Archaeologist"), scientists,
[cartographers](/wiki/Cartographer "Cartographer") and engineers scouring
northern Egypt.[41][42] Their findings, recorded in the _[Description de
l'Égypte](/wiki/Description_de_l%27%C3%89gypte "Description de l'Égypte")_,
include detailed maps that depict the discovery of an ancient canal extending
northward from the Red Sea and then westward toward the Nile.[41][43]

Later, Napoleon, who would become French Emperor in 1804, contemplated the
construction of a north–south canal to connect the Mediterranean with the Red
Sea. But the plan was abandoned because it wrongly concluded that the waterway
would require locks to operate. These would be very expensive and take a long
time to construct. This decision was based on an erroneous belief that the Red
Sea was 10 m (33 ft) higher than the Mediterranean. The error was the result
of using fragmentary survey measurements taken in wartime during Napoleon's
Egyptian Expedition.[44] In 1819 the Pacha of Egypt undertook some canal
work.[45]

However, as late as 1861, the unnavigable ancient route discovered by Napoleon
from [Bubastis](/wiki/Bubastis "Bubastis") to the Red Sea still channeled
water in spots as far east as [Kassassin](/wiki/Kassassin "Kassassin").[10]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: History")]

### Interim period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Interim period")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Suez1856.jpg/220px-
Suez1856.jpg)](/wiki/File:Suez1856.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Suez1856.jpg "Enlarge")

[Bathymetric chart](/wiki/Bathymetric_chart "Bathymetric chart"), northern
[Gulf of Suez](/wiki/Gulf_of_Suez "Gulf of Suez"), route to
[Cairo](/wiki/Old_Cairo "Old Cairo"), 1856

Although the alleged difference in sea levels could be problematic for
construction, the idea of finding a shorter route to the east remained alive.
In 1830, [F. R. Chesney](/wiki/Francis_Rawdon_Chesney "Francis Rawdon
Chesney") submitted a report to the British government that stated that there
was no difference in elevation and that the Suez Canal was feasible, but his
report received no further attention. [Lieutenant
Waghorn](/wiki/Thomas_Fletcher_Waghorn "Thomas Fletcher Waghorn") established
his "Overland Route", which transported post and passengers to India via
Egypt. [Linant de Bellefonds](/wiki/Louis_Maurice_Adolphe_Linant_de_Bellefonds
"Louis Maurice Adolphe Linant de Bellefonds"), a French explorer of Egypt,
became chief engineer of [Egypt's Public Works](/wiki/Egyptian_Public_Works
"Egyptian Public Works"). In addition to his normal duties, he surveyed the
[Isthmus of Suez](/wiki/Isthmus_of_Suez "Isthmus of Suez") and made plans for
the Suez Canal. French [Saint-Simonianists](/wiki/Saint-Simonianism "Saint-
Simonianism") showed an interest in the canal and in 1833, [Barthélemy Prosper
Enfantin](/wiki/Barth%C3%A9lemy_Prosper_Enfantin "Barthélemy Prosper
Enfantin") tried to draw [Muhammad Ali's](/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Pasha "Muhammad
Ali Pasha") attention to the canal but was unsuccessful. [Alois
Negrelli](/wiki/Alois_Negrelli "Alois Negrelli"), the
[Austrian](/wiki/Austrian_Empire "Austrian Empire") railroad pioneer, became
interested in the idea in 1836. In 1846, Prosper Enfantin's [Société d'Études
du Canal de Suez](/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_d%27%C3%89tudes_du_Canal_de_Suez
"Société d'Études du Canal de Suez") invited a number of experts, among them
[Robert Stephenson](/wiki/Robert_Stephenson "Robert Stephenson"), Negrelli and
[Paul-Adrien Bourdaloue](/wiki/Paul-Adrien_Bourdaloue "Paul-Adrien
Bourdaloue") to study the feasibility of the Suez Canal (with the assistance
of Linant de Bellefonds). Bourdaloue's survey of the isthmus was the first
generally accepted evidence that there was no practical difference in altitude
between the two seas. Britain, however, feared that a canal open to everyone
might interfere with its [India](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") trade and
therefore preferred a connection by train from [Alexandria](/wiki/Alexandria
"Alexandria") via [Cairo](/wiki/Cairo "Cairo") to Suez, which was eventually
built by Stephenson.

### Construction by the Suez Canal
Company[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Construction by the Suez Canal Company")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/SuezCanalKantara.jpg/220px-
SuezCanalKantara.jpg)](/wiki/File:SuezCanalKantara.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SuezCanalKantara.jpg "Enlarge")

Suez Canal, 1869

In 1854 and 1856, [Ferdinand de Lesseps](/wiki/Ferdinand_de_Lesseps "Ferdinand
de Lesseps") obtained a concession from [Sa'id Pasha](/wiki/Sa%27id_of_Egypt
"Sa'id of Egypt"), the [Khedive](/wiki/Khedive "Khedive") of [Egypt and
Sudan](/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt "Khedivate of Egypt"), to create a company to
construct a canal open to ships of all nations. The company was to operate the
canal for 99 years from its opening. De Lesseps had used his friendly
relationship with Sa'id, which he had developed while he was a French diplomat
in the 1830s. As stipulated in the concessions, Ferdinand convened the
[International Commission for the piercing of the isthmus of
Suez](/wiki/International_Commission_for_the_piercing_of_the_isthmus_of_Suez
"International Commission for the piercing of the isthmus of Suez")
(_Commission Internationale pour le percement de l 'isthme des Suez_)
consisting of 13 experts from seven countries, among them [John Robinson
McClean](/wiki/John_Robinson_McClean "John Robinson McClean"), later President
of the [Institution of Civil Engineers](/wiki/Institution_of_Civil_Engineers
"Institution of Civil Engineers") in London, and again Negrelli, to examine
the plans developed by [Linant de
Bellefonds](/wiki/Louis_Maurice_Adolphe_Linant_de_Bellefonds "Louis Maurice
Adolphe Linant de Bellefonds"), and to advise on the feasibility of and the
best route for the canal. After surveys and analyses in Egypt and discussions
in Paris on various aspects of the canal, where many of Negrelli's ideas
prevailed, the commission produced a unanimous report in December 1856
containing a detailed description of the canal complete with plans and
profiles.[46] The Suez Canal Company (_[Compagnie universelle du canal
maritime de Suez](/wiki/Compagnie_universelle_du_canal_maritime_de_Suez
"Compagnie universelle du canal maritime de Suez")_) came into being on 15
December 1858 and work started on the shore of the future Port Said on 25
April 1859.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Suez_Canal_drawing_1881.jpg/170px-
Suez_Canal_drawing_1881.jpg)](/wiki/File:Suez_Canal_drawing_1881.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Suez_Canal_drawing_1881.jpg "Enlarge")

1881 drawing of the Suez Canal

The excavation took some 10 years using [forced labour](/wiki/Forced_labour
"Forced labour") ([corvée](/wiki/Corv%C3%A9e "Corvée")) of Egyptian workers
during the first years. Some sources estimate that over 30,000 people were
working on the canal at any given period, that more than 1.5 million people
from various countries were employed, and that thousands of labourers died,
many of them from cholera and similar epidemics.[47][48]

The British government had opposed the project from the outset to its
completion. As one of the diplomatic moves against the canal, it disapproved
of the use of "slave labour" of forced workers. The [British
Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") was the major global naval
force and officially condemned the forced work and sent armed
[Bedouins](/wiki/Bedouin "Bedouin") to start a revolt among workers.
Involuntary labour on the project ceased, and the viceroy condemned the
corvée, halting the project.[49]

Angered by the British opportunism, de Lesseps sent a letter to the British
government remarking on the British lack of remorse a few years earlier when
forced workers died in similar conditions building the British railway in
Egypt.

Initially international opinion was skeptical and Suez Canal Company shares
did not sell well overseas. Britain, [Austria](/wiki/Austrian_Empire "Austrian
Empire"), and [Russia](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") did not buy a
significant number of shares. However, with assistance from the Cattaui
banking family, and their relationship with [James de
Rothschild](/wiki/James_Mayer_de_Rothschild "James Mayer de Rothschild") of
the [French House of Rothschild](/wiki/Rothschild_banking_family_of_France
"Rothschild banking family of France") bonds and shares were successfully
promoted in France and other parts of Europe.[50] All French shares were
quickly sold in France. A contemporary British skeptic claimed "One thing is
sure... our local merchant community doesn't pay practical attention at all to
this grand work, and it is legitimate to doubt that the canal's receipts...
could ever be sufficient to recover its maintenance fee. It will never become
a large ship's accessible way in any case."[51]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Suez_Canal%2C_Egypt._Lantern_Slide.jpg/220px-
Suez_Canal%2C_Egypt._Lantern_Slide.jpg)](/wiki/File:Suez_Canal,_Egypt._Lantern_Slide.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Suez_Canal,_Egypt._Lantern_Slide.jpg "Enlarge")

Suez Canal, Egypt. early 1900s. Goodyear Archival Collection. [Brooklyn
Museum](/wiki/Brooklyn_Museum "Brooklyn Museum")

The canal opened under French control on 17 November 1869. Although numerous
technical, political, and financial problems had been overcome, the [final
cost](/wiki/Cost_overrun "Cost overrun") was more than double the original
estimate. The opening was performed by [Khedive](/wiki/Khedive "Khedive")
[Isma'il Pasha](/wiki/Isma%27il_Pasha "Isma'il Pasha") of [Egypt and
Sudan](/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt "Khedivate of Egypt"), and at Ismail's
invitation [French Empress Eugenie](/wiki/Eug%C3%A9nie_de_Montijo "Eugénie de
Montijo") in the Imperial yacht _L 'Aigle_ piloted by Napoléon Coste, upon
whom the [Khedive](/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt "Khedivate of Egypt") bestowed the
[Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") [Order of the
Medjidie](/wiki/Order_of_the_Medjidie "Order of the Medjidie"). The Khedive,
in particular, was able to overcome initial reservations held by both British
and French creditors by enlisting the help of the [Sursock
Family](/wiki/Sursock_family "Sursock family"), whose deep connections proved
invaluable in securing much international support for the project. [52]

The first ship to follow _L 'Aigle_ through the canal was the British
[P&O](/wiki/P%26O_\(company\) "P&O \(company\)") liner _Delta_.[53][54] Fourth
ship through the canal was the Swedish steam frigate _Vanadis_.[55] Although
_L 'Aigle_ was officially the first vessel through the canal, [HMS
_Newport_](/wiki/HMS_Newport_\(1867\) "HMS Newport \(1867\)"), captained by
[George Nares](/wiki/George_Nares "George Nares"), passed through it first. On
the night before the canal was due to open, Captain Nares navigated his
vessel, in total darkness and without lights, through the mass of waiting
ships until it was in front of _L 'Aigle_. When dawn broke, the French were
horrified to find that the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") was
first in line and that it would be impossible to pass them. Nares received
both an official reprimand and an unofficial vote of thanks from the
[Admiralty](/wiki/Admiralty "Admiralty") for his actions in promoting British
interests and for demonstrating such superb seamanship.[56] An Anchor Line
ship, the S.S. _Dido_ , became the first to pass through the Canal from South
to North[57][58].

After the opening, the Suez Canal Company was in financial difficulties. The
remaining works were completed only in 1871, and traffic was below
expectations in the first two years. De Lesseps therefore tried to increase
revenues by interpreting the kind of net ton referred to in the second
concession (_tonneau de capacité_) as meaning a ship's cargo capacity and not
only the theoretical [net tonnage](/wiki/Net_tonnage "Net tonnage") of the
"[Moorsom System](/wiki/Moorsom_System "Moorsom System")" introduced in
Britain by the Merchant Shipping Act in 1854. The ensuing commercial and
diplomatic activities resulted in the International Commission of
Constantinople establishing a specific kind of net tonnage and settling the
question of tariffs in its protocol of 18 December 1873.[59] This was the
origin of the [Suez Canal Net Tonnage](/wiki/Net_Register_Tonnage "Net
Register Tonnage") and the [Suez Canal Special Tonnage
Certificate](/wiki/Net_Register_Tonnage "Net Register Tonnage"), both of which
are still in use today.

### Company rule after
opening[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Company rule after opening")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Suez_Canal_%28ca_1914%29.jpg/220px-
Suez_Canal_%28ca_1914%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Suez_Canal_\(ca_1914\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Suez_Canal_\(ca_1914\).jpg "Enlarge")

Suez Canal, ca 1914

The canal had an immediate and dramatic effect on [world
trade](/wiki/Global_trade "Global trade"). Combined with the [American
transcontinental railroad](/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Railroad "First
Transcontinental Railroad") completed six months earlier, it allowed the world
to be circled in record time. It played an important role in increasing
[European colonization of Africa](/wiki/European_colonization_of_Africa
"European colonization of Africa"). The construction of the canal was one of
the reasons for the [Panic of 1873](/wiki/Panic_of_1873 "Panic of 1873"),
because goods from the Far East were carried in sailing vessels around the
[Cape of Good Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope "Cape of Good Hope") and were
stored in British warehouses. An inability to pay his bank debts led Said
Pasha's successor, [Isma'il Pasha](/wiki/Isma%27il_Pasha "Isma'il Pasha"), to
sell his 44% share in the canal for £4,000,000 (about £89.1 million in 2017)
to the government of Great Britain in 1875. French shareholders still held the
majority. [60] Local unrest caused the British to invade in 1882 and take full
control, although nominally Egypt remained part of the Ottoman Empire. The
British representative 1883 to 1907 was [Evelyn Baring, 1st Earl of
Cromer](/wiki/Evelyn_Baring,_1st_Earl_of_Cromer "Evelyn Baring, 1st Earl of
Cromer"), who reorganized and modernized the government and suppressed
rebellions and corruption. thereby facilitating increased traffic on the
canal.[61]

The [Convention of Constantinople](/wiki/Convention_of_Constantinople
"Convention of Constantinople") in 1888 declared the canal a neutral zone
under the protection of the British, who had occupied Egypt and Sudan at the
request of [Khedive](/wiki/Khedive "Khedive") [Tewfiq](/wiki/Tewfik_Pasha
"Tewfik Pasha") to suppress the [Urabi Revolt](/wiki/Urabi_Revolt "Urabi
Revolt") against his rule. The revolt went on from 1879 to 1882. As a result
of British involvement on the side of Khedive Tewfiq, Britain gained control
of the canal in 1882. The British defended the strategically important passage
against a major [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire")
[attack](/wiki/First_Suez_Offensive "First Suez Offensive") in 1915, during
the [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War").[62] Under the
[Anglo-Egyptian Treaty of 1936](/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_Treaty_of_1936 "Anglo-
Egyptian Treaty of 1936"), the UK retained control over the canal. The canal
was again strategically important in the 1939–1945 [Second World
War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War"), and Italo-German attempts to
capture it were repulsed during the [North Africa
Campaign](/wiki/North_Africa_Campaign "North Africa Campaign"), during which
the canal was closed to [Axis](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers") shipping. In
1951 Egypt repudiated the treaty and in October 1954 the UK agreed to remove
its troops. Withdrawal was completed on 18 July 1956.

### Suez Crisis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Suez Crisis")]

Main article: [Suez Crisis](/wiki/Suez_Crisis "Suez Crisis")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Port_Said_from_air.jpg/220px-
Port_Said_from_air.jpg)](/wiki/File:Port_Said_from_air.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Port_Said_from_air.jpg "Enlarge")

Smoke rises from oil tanks beside the Suez Canal hit during the initial
[Anglo-French assault](/wiki/Operation_Musketeer_\(1956\) "Operation Musketeer
\(1956\)") on [Port Said](/wiki/Port_Said "Port Said"), 5 November 1956

Because of Egyptian overtures towards the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union
"Soviet Union"), the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom")
and the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") withdrew their
pledge to support the construction of the [Aswan Dam](/wiki/Aswan_Dam "Aswan
Dam"). Egyptian President [Gamal Abdel Nasser](/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser "Gamal
Abdel Nasser") responded by [nationalizing](/wiki/Nationalizing
"Nationalizing") the canal on 26 July 1956[63] and transferring it to the
[Suez Canal Authority](/wiki/Suez_Canal_Authority "Suez Canal Authority"),
intending to finance the dam project using revenue from the canal. On the same
day that the canal was nationalized Nasser also closed the [Straits of
Tiran](/wiki/Straits_of_Tiran "Straits of Tiran") to all Israeli ships.[64]
This led to the [Suez Crisis](/wiki/Suez_Crisis "Suez Crisis") in which the
UK, France, and [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel") invaded Egypt. According to
the pre-agreed war plans under the [Protocol of
Sèvres](/wiki/Protocol_of_S%C3%A8vres "Protocol of Sèvres"), the Israelis
invaded the [Sinai Peninsula](/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula "Sinai Peninsula") on 29
October, forcing Egypt to engage them militarily, and allowing the [Anglo-
French](/wiki/Operation_Musketeer_\(1956\) "Operation Musketeer \(1956\)")
partnership to declare the resultant fighting a threat to stability in the
Middle East and enter the war - officially to separate the two forces but in
reality to regain the Canal and bring down the Nasser government.

To save the British from what he thought was a disastrous action and to stop
the war from a possible escalation, Canadian Secretary of State for External
Affairs [Lester B. Pearson](/wiki/Lester_B._Pearson "Lester B. Pearson")
proposed the creation of the first United Nations peacekeeping force to ensure
access to the canal for all and an Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai
Peninsula. On 4 November 1956, a majority at the United Nations voted for
Pearson's peacekeeping resolution, which
[mandated](/wiki/Mandate_\(international_law\) "Mandate \(international
law\)") the UN peacekeepers to stay in Sinai unless both Egypt and Israel
agreed to their withdrawal. The United States backed this proposal by putting
pressure on the British government through the selling of
[sterling](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling"), which would cause it to
depreciate. Britain then called a ceasefire, and later agreed to withdraw its
troops by the end of the year. Pearson was later awarded the [Nobel Peace
Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize "Nobel Peace Prize"). As a result of damage and
ships sunk under orders from Nasser the canal was closed until April 1957,
when it was cleared with UN assistance.[65] A UN force
([UNEF](/wiki/United_Nations_Emergency_Force "United Nations Emergency
Force")) was established to maintain the free navigability of the canal, and
peace in the Sinai Peninsula.

According to the historian [Abd aI-Azim Ramadan](/w/index.php?title=Abd_aI-
Azim_Ramadan&action=edit&redlink=1 "Abd aI-Azim Ramadan \(page does not
exist\)"), Nasser's decision to nationalize the Suez Canal was his alone, made
without political or military consultation. The events leading up to the
nationalization of the Suez Canal Company, as other events during Nasser’s
rule, showed Nasser’s inclination to solitary decision making. Ramadan
considered Nasser to be far from a rational, responsible leader.[66]

### Arab–Israeli wars of 1967 and
1973[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Arab–Israeli wars of 1967 and 1973")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Egyptianbridge.jpg/220px-
Egyptianbridge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Egyptianbridge.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Egyptianbridge.jpg "Enlarge")

Egyptian vehicles crossing the Suez Canal on 7 October 1973, during the [Yom
Kippur War](/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War "Yom Kippur War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Israeli_Tanks_Cross_the_Suez_Canal_-
_Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces.jpg/220px-Israeli_Tanks_Cross_the_Suez_Canal_-
_Flickr_-
_Israel_Defense_Forces.jpg)](/wiki/File:Israeli_Tanks_Cross_the_Suez_Canal_-
_Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Israeli_Tanks_Cross_the_Suez_Canal_-_Flickr_-
_Israel_Defense_Forces.jpg "Enlarge")

Israeli tank crossing the Suez Canal, 1973

In May 1967, Nasser ordered the UN peacekeeping forces out of Sinai, including
the Suez Canal area. Israel objected to the closing of the [Straits of
Tiran](/wiki/Straits_of_Tiran "Straits of Tiran") to Israeli shipping. The
canal had been closed to Israeli shipping since 1949, except for a short
period in 1951–1952.

After the 1967 [Six-Day War](/wiki/Six-Day_War "Six-Day War"), Israeli forces
occupied the Sinai peninsula, including the entire east bank of the Suez
Canal. Unwilling to allow the Israelis to use the canal, Egypt immediately
imposed a blockade which closed the canal to all shipping until 5 June 1975.
As a result, 15 cargo ships, known as the "[Yellow Fleet](/wiki/Yellow_Fleet
"Yellow Fleet")", were trapped in the canal for over eight years.

In 1973, during the [Yom Kippur War](/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War "Yom Kippur War"),
the canal was the scene of [a major crossing](/wiki/Operation_Badr_\(1973\)
"Operation Badr \(1973\)") by the Egyptian army into Israeli-occupied Sinai
and a counter-crossing by the [Israeli army](/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces
"Israel Defense Forces") to Egypt. Much wreckage from this conflict remains
visible along the canal's edges.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] After
the Yom Kippur War the United States initiated [Operation Nimbus
Moon](/wiki/Operation_Nimbus_Moon "Operation Nimbus Moon"). The [amphibious
assault ship](/wiki/Amphibious_assault_ship "Amphibious assault ship") [USS
_Inchon (LPH-12)_](/wiki/USS_Inchon_\(LPH-12\) "USS Inchon \(LPH-12\)") was
sent to the Canal, carrying 12 [RH-53D](/wiki/CH-53_Sea_Stallion "CH-53 Sea
Stallion") minesweeping helicopters of
[HM-12](/w/index.php?title=Helicopter_Mine_Countermeasures_Squadron_12&action=edit&redlink=1
"Helicopter Mine Countermeasures Squadron 12 \(page does not exist\)"). These
partly cleared the canal between May and December 1974. She was relieved by
the LST [USS _Barnstable County_](/wiki/USS_Barnstable_County "USS Barnstable
County") (LST1197). The British [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy")
initiated [Operation
Rheostat](/w/index.php?title=Operation_Rheostat&action=edit&redlink=1
"Operation Rheostat \(page does not exist\)") and Task Group 65.2 provided for
Operation Rheostat One[67] (six months in 1974), the minehunters [HMS
_Maxton_](/w/index.php?title=HMS_Maxton&action=edit&redlink=1 "HMS Maxton
\(page does not exist\)"), [HMS
_Bossington_](/w/index.php?title=HMS_Bossington&action=edit&redlink=1 "HMS
Bossington \(page does not exist\)"), and [HMS
_Wilton_](/wiki/HMS_Wilton_\(M1116\) "HMS Wilton \(M1116\)"), the Fleet
Clearance Diving Team (FCDT)[68] and [HMS _Abdiel_](/wiki/HMS_Abdiel_\(N21\)
"HMS Abdiel \(N21\)"), a practice minelayer/MCMV support ship; and for
Operation Rheostat Two[69] (six months in 1975) the minehunters HMS Hubberston
and HMS Sheraton, and HMS Abdiel. When the Canal Clearance Operations were
completed, the canal and its lakes were considered 99% clear of mines. The
canal was then reopened by Egyptian President [Anwar Sadat](/wiki/Anwar_Sadat
"Anwar Sadat") aboard an Egyptian destroyer, which led the first convoy
northbound to Port Said in 1975.[70] At his side stood the Iranian Crown
Prince [Reza Pahlavi](/wiki/Reza_Pahlavi,_Crown_Prince_of_Iran "Reza Pahlavi,
Crown Prince of Iran"), delegated to represent his father, [Mohammed Reza
Pahlavi](/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi "Mohammad Reza Pahlavi"), the Shah of
Iran. The cruiser [USS _Little Rock_](/wiki/USS_Little_Rock_\(CL-92\) "USS
Little Rock \(CL-92\)") was the only American naval ship in the convoy.[71]

The [UNEF](/wiki/United_Nations_Emergency_Force "United Nations Emergency
Force") mandate expired in 1979. Despite the efforts of the United States,
Israel, Egypt, and others to obtain an extension of the UN role in observing
the peace between Israel and Egypt, as called for under the [Egypt–Israel
Peace Treaty](/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_Peace_Treaty "Egypt–Israel Peace
Treaty") of 1979, the mandate could not be extended because of the veto by the
[Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") in the [UN Security
Council](/wiki/UN_Security_Council "UN Security Council"), at the request of
[Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria"). Accordingly, negotiations for a new observer
force in the Sinai produced the [Multinational Force and
Observers](/wiki/Multinational_Force_and_Observers "Multinational Force and
Observers") (MFO), stationed in Sinai in 1981 in coordination with a phased
Israeli withdrawal. It is there under agreements between the United States,
Israel, Egypt, and other nations.[72]

### Bypass
expansion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Bypass expansion")]

Main article: [New Suez Canal](/wiki/New_Suez_Canal "New Suez Canal")

In the summer of 2014, months after taking office as [President of
Egypt](/wiki/President_of_Egypt "President of Egypt"), [Abdel Fattah el-
Sisi](/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi "Abdel Fattah el-Sisi") ordered the expansion
of the Ballah Bypass from 61 metres wide to 312 metres wide for 35 kilometers.
The project was called the [New Suez Canal](/wiki/New_Suez_Canal "New Suez
Canal"), as it would allow ships to transit the canal in both directions
simultaneously.[73][74] The project cost more than $8 billion and was
completed within one year. Sisi declared the expanded channel open for
business in a ceremony on 6 August 2015.[75]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/SuezCanal4_byDanielCsorfoly.JPG/220px-
SuezCanal4_byDanielCsorfoly.JPG)](/wiki/File:SuezCanal4_byDanielCsorfoly.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:SuezCanal4_byDanielCsorfoly.JPG "Enlarge")

Container ship _Hanjin Kaohsiung_ transiting the Suez Canal

  * Circa 1799 – Napoleon Bonaparte conquers Egypt and orders a feasibility analysis. This reports a supposed 10-metre (33 ft) difference in sea levels and a high cost, so the project is put on hold.
  * Circa 1840 – A second survey finds the first analysis incorrect. A direct link between the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea is possible and not as expensive as previously estimated.
  * 30 November 1854 – The former French consul in Cairo, Ferdinand Marie de Lesseps, obtains the first license for construction and subsequent operation from the Viceroy for a period of 99 years.
  * 6 January 1856 – de Lesseps is provided with a second, more detailed license.
  * 15 December 1858 – de Lesseps establishes the "Compagnie Universelle du Canal Maritime de Suez", with [Said Pasha](/wiki/Said_of_Egypt "Said of Egypt") acquiring 22% of the Suez Canal Company; the majority is controlled by French private holders.
  * 25 April 1859 – construction officially starts.
  * 17 November 1869 – The canal is opened, owned and operated by Suez Canal Company.
  * 18 December 1873 – The International Commission of Constantinople establishes the Suez Canal Net Ton and the Suez Canal Special Tonnage Certificate (as known today)
  * 25 November 1875 – Britain becomes a minority share holder in the company, acquiring 44%, with the remainder being controlled by French business syndicates.
  * 20 May 1882 – Britain [invades](/wiki/Battle_of_Tel_el-Kebir "Battle of Tel el-Kebir") Egypt, with French assistance, and begins its occupation of Egypt.
  * 25 August 1882 – Britain takes control of the canal.
  * 2 March 1888 – The [Convention of Constantinople](/wiki/Convention_of_Constantinople "Convention of Constantinople") renews the guaranteed right of passage of all ships through the canal during war and peace; these rights were already part of the licenses awarded to de Lesseps, but are recognised as international law.
  * 14 November 1936 – Following a [new treaty](/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_Treaty_of_1936 "Anglo-Egyptian Treaty of 1936"), Britain theoretically pulls out of Egypt, but establishes the 'Suez Canal Zone' under its control.
  * 13 June 1956 – Suez Canal Zone is restored to Egyptian sovereignty, following British withdrawal and years of negotiations.
  * 26 July 1956 – Egypt nationalizes the company; its Egyptian assets, rights and obligations are transferred to the Suez Canal Authority, which compensates the previous owners at the established pre-nationalization price. Egypt closes the canal to Israeli shipping as part of a broader blockade involving the Straits of Tiran and the Gulf of Aqaba.
  * 31 October 1956 to 24 April 1957 – the canal is blocked to shipping following the [Suez Crisis](/wiki/Suez_Crisis "Suez Crisis"), a conflict that leads to an Israeli, French and British occupation of the canal zone.
  * 22 December 1956 – The canal zone is restored to Egyptian control, following French and British withdrawal, and the landing of [UNEF](/wiki/United_Nations_Emergency_Force "United Nations Emergency Force") troops.
  * 5 June 1967 to 10 June 1975 – the canal is blocked by Egypt, following the [war with Israel](/wiki/Six-Day_War "Six-Day War"); it becomes the front line during the ensuing [War of Attrition](/wiki/War_of_Attrition "War of Attrition") and the [1973 war](/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War "Yom Kippur War"), remaining closed to international shipping, until [general agreement](/wiki/Sinai_Interim_Agreement "Sinai Interim Agreement") was near.
  * 1 January 2008 – New rules of navigation passed by the Suez Canal Authority come into force.
  * 6 August 2015 – The new canal extensions are opened.

Ferdinand de Lesseps, developer of the Suez Canal

Presidents of the Suez Canal Company (1858–1956):

  * [Ferdinand de Lesseps](/wiki/Ferdinand_de_Lesseps "Ferdinand de Lesseps") (15 December 1858 – 7 December 1894)
  * Jules Guichard (17 December 1892 – 17 July 1896) (acting for de Lesseps to 7 December 1894)
  * [Auguste-Louis-Albéric, prince d'Arenberg](/wiki/Auguste-Louis-Alb%C3%A9ric,_prince_d%27Arenberg "Auguste-Louis-Albéric, prince d'Arenberg") (3 August 1896 – 1913)
  * [Charles Jonnart](/wiki/Charles_Jonnart "Charles Jonnart") (19 May 1913 – 1927)
  * Louis de Vogüé (4 April 1927 – 1 March 1948)
  * [François Charles-Roux](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Charles-Roux "François Charles-Roux") (4 April 1948 – 26 July 1956)

Chairmen of the Suez Canal Authority (1956–present):

  * [Doctor](/wiki/Doctor_\(title\) "Doctor \(title\)") Mohamed Helmy Bahgat Badawy (26 July 1956 – 9 July 1957)
  * Engineer [Mahmoud Younis](/wiki/Mahmoud_Younis "Mahmoud Younis") (10 July 1957 – 10 October 1965)
  * Engineer [Mashhour Ahmed Mashhour](/wiki/Mashhour_Ahmed_Mashhour "Mashhour Ahmed Mashhour") (14 October 1965 – 31 December 1983)
  * Engineer Mohamed Ezzat Adel (1 January 1984 – December 1995)
  * [Admiral](/wiki/Admiral "Admiral") Ahmed Ali Fadel (22 January 1996 – Aug 2012)
  * [Admiral](/wiki/Admiral "Admiral") [Mohab Mamish](/wiki/Mohab_Mamish "Mohab Mamish") (2012 – present)

When built, the canal was 164 km (102 mi) long and 8 m (26 ft) deep. After
several enlargements, it is 193.30 km (120.11 mi) long, 24 m (79 ft) deep and
205 metres (673 ft) wide.[77] It consists of the northern access
[channel](/wiki/Channel_\(geography\) "Channel \(geography\)") of 22 km (14
mi), the canal itself of 162.25 km (100.82 mi) and the southern access channel
of 9 km (5.6 mi).[78]

The so-called _[New Suez Canal](/wiki/New_Suez_Canal "New Suez Canal")_ ,
functional since 6 August 2015,[79] currently has a new parallel canal in the
middle part, with its length over 35 km (22 mi). The current parameters of the
Suez Canal, including both individual canals of the parallel section are:
depth 23 to 24 metres (75 to 79 ft) and width at least 205 to 225 metres (673
to 738 ft) (that width measured at 11 metres (36 ft) of depth).[80]

### Capacity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Capacity")]

See also: [Suezmax](/wiki/Suezmax "Suezmax")

The canal allows passage of ships up to 20 m (66 ft)
[draft](/wiki/Draft_\(hull\) "Draft \(hull\)") or 240,000 [deadweight
tons](/wiki/Deadweight_ton "Deadweight ton") and up to a height of 68 m (223
ft) above water level and a maximum [beam](/wiki/Beam_\(nautical\) "Beam
\(nautical\)") of 77.5 m (254 ft) under certain conditions.[81][82] The canal
can handle more traffic and larger ships than the [Panama
Canal](/wiki/Panama_Canal "Panama Canal"), as [Suezmax](/wiki/Suezmax
"Suezmax") dimensions are greater than both [Panamax](/wiki/Panamax "Panamax")
and [New Panamax](/wiki/New_Panamax "New Panamax"). Some supertankers are too
large to traverse the canal. Others can offload part of their cargo onto a
canal-owned boat to reduce their draft, transit, and reload at the other end
of the canal.

### Navigation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Navigation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/SuezCanal_ElBallah.JPG/220px-
SuezCanal_ElBallah.JPG)](/wiki/File:SuezCanal_ElBallah.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:SuezCanal_ElBallah.JPG "Enlarge")

Ships moored at El Ballah during transit

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/MEDCURR.GIF/220px-
MEDCURR.GIF)](/wiki/File:MEDCURR.GIF)

[](/wiki/File:MEDCURR.GIF "Enlarge")

Predominant currents in the [Mediterranean Sea](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea
"Mediterranean Sea") for June

The canal has no [locks](/wiki/Canal_lock "Canal lock") because of the flat
terrain, and the minor sea level difference between each end is
inconsequential for shipping. As the canal has no sea surge gates, the ports
at the ends would be subject to the sudden impact of [tsunamis](/wiki/Tsunami
"Tsunami") from the Mediterranean Sea and Red Sea, according to a 2012 article
in the _Journal of Coastal Research_.[83]

There is one shipping lane with passing areas in Ballah-Bypass near [El
Qantara](/wiki/El_Qantara "El Qantara") and in the Great Bitter Lake. On a
typical day, three convoys transit the canal, two southbound and one
northbound. The passage takes between 11 and 16 hours at a speed of around 8
knots (15 km/h; 9 mph). The low speed helps prevent erosion of the banks by
ships' [wakes](/wiki/Wake "Wake").

By 1955, about two-thirds of Europe's oil passed through the canal. Around 8%
of world sea trade is carried via the canal. In 2008, 21,415 vessels passed
through the canal and the receipts totaled $5.381 billion,[81] with an average
cost per ship of $251,000.

New Rules of Navigation came into force on 1 January 2008, passed by the board
of directors of the [Suez Canal Authority](/wiki/Suez_Canal_Authority "Suez
Canal Authority") (SCA) to organise vessels' transit. The most important
amendments include allowing vessels with 62-foot (19 m) draught to pass,
increasing the allowed breadth from 32 metres (105 ft) to 40 metres (130 ft)
(following improvement operations), and imposing a fine on vessels using
divers from outside the SCA inside the canal boundaries without permission.
The amendments allow vessels loaded with dangerous cargo (such as radioactive
or flammable materials) to pass if they conform with the latest amendments
provided by international conventions.

The SCA has the right to determine the number of [tugs](/wiki/Tugboat
"Tugboat") required to assist warships traversing the canal, to achieve the
highest degree of safety during transit.[84]

### Operation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Operation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG/220px-
Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG)](/wiki/File:Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG "Enlarge")

Post-deepening, a [capesize](/wiki/Capesize "Capesize") [bulk
carrier](/wiki/Bulk_carrier "Bulk carrier") approaches the [Friendship
Bridge](/wiki/Suez_Canal_Bridge "Suez Canal Bridge")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Bittersee_suezkanal.JPG/220px-
Bittersee_suezkanal.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bittersee_suezkanal.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Bittersee_suezkanal.JPG "Enlarge")

Northbound convoy waits in the Great Bitter Lake as southbound convoy passes,
October 2014

Before August 2015, the canal was too narrow for free two-way traffic, so
ships would pass in convoys and use bypasses. The by-passes were 78 km (48 mi)
out of 193 km (120 mi) (40%). From north to south, they are: Port Said by-pass
(entrances) 36.5 km (23 mi), Ballah by-pass & anchorage, 9 km (6 mi), Timsah
by-pass 5 km (3 mi), and the Deversoir by-pass (northern end of the Great
Bitter Lake) 27.5 km (17 mi). The bypasses were completed in 1980.

Typically, it would take a ship 12 to 16 hours to transit the canal. The
canal's 24-hour capacity was about 76 standard ships.[85]

In August 2014, Egypt chose a consortium that includes the Egyptian army and
global engineering firm [Dar Al-Handasah](/wiki/Dar_Al-Handasah "Dar Al-
Handasah") to develop an international industrial and logistics hub in the
Suez Canal area,[86] and began the construction of a new canal section from km
60 to km 95 combined with expansion and deep digging of the other 37 km of the
canal.[87] This will allow navigation in both directions simultaneously in the
72 km long central section of the canal. These extensions were formally opened
on 6 August 2015 by President Al-Sisi.[6][88][89]

### Convoy sailing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Convoy sailing")]

Since the canal does not cater to unregulated two-way traffic, all ships
transit in convoys on regular times, scheduled on a 24-hour basis. Each day, a
single northbound convoy starts at 04:00 from Suez. At dulka lane sections,
the convoy uses the eastern route.[90][91][92] Synchronised with this convoy's
passage is the southbound convoy. It starts at 03:30 from Port Said and so
passes the Northbound convoy in the two-lane section[_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_].

### Canal
crossings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=23 "Edit
section: Canal crossings")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Suez_canal_english.jpg/220px-
Suez_canal_english.jpg)](/wiki/File:Suez_canal_english.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Suez_canal_english.jpg "Enlarge")

The canal in 2015

From north to south, the crossings are:

  * The [Suez Canal Bridge](/wiki/Suez_Canal_Bridge "Suez Canal Bridge") ([30°49′42″N 32°19′03″E﻿ / ﻿30.828248°N 32.317572°E﻿ / 30.828248; 32.317572﻿ (Suez Canal Bridge)](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Suez_Canal&params=30.828248_N_32.317572_E_region:EG_type:landmark&title=Suez+Canal+Bridge)), also called the Egyptian-Japanese Friendship Bridge, a high-level road bridge at [El Qantara](/wiki/El_Qantara "El Qantara"). In [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic"), _al qantara_ means "arch". Opened in 2001, it has a 70-metre (230 ft) clearance over the canal and was built with assistance from the Japanese government and by [Kajima](/wiki/Kajima "Kajima").[93]
  * [El Ferdan Railway Bridge](/wiki/El_Ferdan_Railway_Bridge "El Ferdan Railway Bridge") ([30°39′25″N 32°20′02″E﻿ / ﻿30.657°N 32.334°E﻿ / 30.657; 32.334﻿ (El Ferdan Railway Bridge)](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Suez_Canal&params=30.657_N_32.334_E_source:dewiki&title=El+Ferdan+Railway+Bridge)) 20 km (12 mi) north of [Ismailia](/wiki/Ismailia "Ismailia") ([30°35′N 32°16′E﻿ / ﻿30.583°N 32.267°E﻿ / 30.583; 32.267﻿ (Ismailia)](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Suez_Canal&params=30_35_N_32_16_E_&title=Ismailia)) was completed in 2001 and is the longest [swing-span bridge](/wiki/Swing_bridge "Swing bridge") in the world, with a span of 340 m (1100 ft). The previous bridge was destroyed in 1967 during the Arab-Israeli conflict. The current bridge is no longer functional due to the expansion of the Suez Canal, as the parallel shipping lane completed in 2015 just east of the bridge lacks a structure spanning it.
  * Pipelines taking fresh water under the canal to [Sinai](/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula "Sinai Peninsula"), about 57 km (35 mi) north of Suez, at [30°27.3′N 32°21.0′E﻿ / ﻿30.4550°N 32.3500°E﻿ / 30.4550; 32.3500﻿ (Fresh-water pipelines)](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Suez_Canal&params=30_27.3_N_32_21.0_E_&title=Fresh-water+pipelines).
  * [Ahmed Hamdi Tunnel](/wiki/Ahmed_Hamdi_Tunnel "Ahmed Hamdi Tunnel") ([30°5′9″N 32°34′32″E﻿ / ﻿30.08583°N 32.57556°E﻿ / 30.08583; 32.57556﻿ (Ahmed Hamdi Tunnel)](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Suez_Canal&params=30_5_9_N_32_34_32_E_source:svwiki_region:EG_type:landmark&title=Ahmed+Hamdi+Tunnel)) south of the Great Bitter Lake ([30°20′N 32°23′E﻿ / ﻿30.333°N 32.383°E﻿ / 30.333; 32.383﻿ (Great Bitter Lake)](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Suez_Canal&params=30_20_N_32_23_E_region:EG_type:waterbody&title=Great+Bitter+Lake)) was built in 1983. Because of leakage problems, a new water-tight tunnel[94] was built inside the old one from 1992 to 1995.
  * The [Suez Canal overhead powerline crossing](/wiki/Suez_Canal_overhead_powerline_crossing "Suez Canal overhead powerline crossing") ([29°59′46″N 32°34′59″E﻿ / ﻿29.996°N 32.583°E﻿ / 29.996; 32.583﻿ (Suez Canal overhead powerline crossing)](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Suez_Canal&params=29.996_N_32.583_E_source:dewiki&title=Suez+Canal+overhead+powerline+crossing)) was built in 1999.

A railway on the west bank runs parallel to the canal for its entire length.

Six new tunnels for cars and trains are also planned across the canal.[95]
Currently the [Ahmed Hamdi](/wiki/Ahmed_Hamdi_Tunnel "Ahmed Hamdi Tunnel") is
the only tunnel connecting [Suez](/wiki/Suez "Suez") to the Sinai.

## Alternative
routes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Alternative routes")]

### Cape Agulhas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Cape Agulhas")]

The main alternative is around [Cape Agulhas](/wiki/Cape_Agulhas "Cape
Agulhas"), the southernmost point of Africa, commonly referred as the [Cape of
Good Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope "Cape of Good Hope") route. This was the
only sea route before the canal was constructed, and when the canal was
closed. It is still the only route for ships that are [too
large](/wiki/Capesize "Capesize") for the canal. In the early 21st century,
the Suez Canal has suffered from diminished traffic due to [piracy in
Somalia](/wiki/Piracy_in_Somalia "Piracy in Somalia"), with many shipping
companies choosing to take the long route instead.[96][97] Between 2008 and
2010, it is estimated that the canal lost 10% of traffic due to the threat of
piracy, and another 10% due to the [financial
crisis](/wiki/Financial_crisis_\(2007%E2%80%93present\) "Financial crisis
\(2007–present\)"). An [oil tanker](/wiki/Oil_tanker "Oil tanker") going from
Saudi Arabia to the United States has 2,700 mi (4,345 km) longer to go when
taking the route south of Africa rather than the canal.[98]

Before the canal's opening in 1869, goods were sometimes offloaded from ships
and carried overland between the Mediterranean and the Red Sea.[99]

### Northern Sea
Route[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Northern Sea Route")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Northern_Sea_Route_vs_Southern_Sea_Route.svg/220px-
Northern_Sea_Route_vs_Southern_Sea_Route.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Northern_Sea_Route_vs_Southern_Sea_Route.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Northern_Sea_Route_vs_Southern_Sea_Route.svg "Enlarge")

A graphical comparison between the [Northern Sea
Route](/wiki/Northern_Sea_Route "Northern Sea Route") (blue) and an
alternative route through Suez Canal (red)

In recent years, the [shrinking](/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_Arctic "Climate
change in the Arctic") [Arctic](/wiki/Arctic "Arctic") [sea ice](/wiki/Sea_ice
"Sea ice") has made the [Northern Sea Route](/wiki/Northern_Sea_Route
"Northern Sea Route") feasible for commercial cargo ships between Europe and
East Asia during a six-to-eight-week window in the summer months, shortening
the voyage by thousands of miles compared to that through the Suez Canal.
According to polar climate researchers, as the extent of the Arctic summer ice
pack recedes the route will become passable without the help of
[icebreakers](/wiki/Icebreaker "Icebreaker") for a greater period each
summer.[100][101][102]

The [Bremen](/wiki/Bremen "Bremen")-based [Beluga Group](/wiki/Beluga_Group
"Beluga Group") claimed in 2009 to be the first Western company to attempt
using the Northern Sea Route without assistance from icebreakers, cutting 4000
nautical miles off the journey between [Ulsan](/wiki/Ulsan "Ulsan"),
[Korea](/wiki/Korea "Korea") and [Rotterdam](/wiki/Rotterdam "Rotterdam"), the
[Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands").[103]

### Negev desert
railroad[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Negev desert railroad")]

[Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel") has declared that it will construct a
[railroad](/wiki/High-speed_railway_to_Eilat "High-speed railway to Eilat")
through the [Negev](/wiki/Negev "Negev") desert to compete with the canal,
with construction partly financed by China.[104]

## Environmental
impact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=28 "Edit
section: Environmental impact")]

Main article: [Lessepsian migration](/wiki/Lessepsian_migration "Lessepsian
migration")

The opening of the canal created the first salt-water passage between the
Mediterranean and the Red Sea. Although the Red Sea is about 1.2 m (4 ft)
higher than the eastern Mediterranean,[105] the current between the
Mediterranean and the middle of the canal at the [Bitter
Lakes](/wiki/Bitter_Lakes "Bitter Lakes") flows north in winter and south in
summer. The current south of the Bitter Lakes is tidal, varying with the tide
at Suez.[3] The Bitter Lakes, which were hypersaline natural lakes, blocked
the migration of Red Sea species into the Mediterranean for many decades, but
as the salinity of the lakes gradually equalised with that of the Red Sea the
barrier to migration was removed, and plants and animals from the Red Sea have
begun to colonise the eastern Mediterranean. The Red Sea is generally saltier
and more nutrient-poor than the [Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic "Atlantic"), so the
Red Sea species have advantages over Atlantic species in the less salty and
nutrient-rich eastern Mediterranean. Accordingly, most Red Sea species invade
the Mediterranean biota, and only few do the opposite. This migratory
phenomenon is called [Lessepsian migration](/wiki/Lessepsian_migration
"Lessepsian migration") (after Ferdinand de Lesseps) or "Erythrean invasion".
Also impacting the eastern Mediterranean, starting in 1968, was the operation
of [Aswan High Dam](/wiki/Aswan_High_Dam "Aswan High Dam") across the Nile.
While providing for increased human development, the project reduced the
inflow of freshwater and ended all natural nutrient-rich silt entering the
eastern Mediterranean at the [Nile Delta](/wiki/Nile_Delta "Nile Delta"). This
provided less natural dilution of Mediterranean salinity and ended the higher
levels of natural [turbidity](/wiki/Turbidity "Turbidity"), additionally
making conditions more like those in the Red Sea.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Invasive species originating from the Red Sea and
[introduced](/wiki/Introduced_species "Introduced species") into the
Mediterranean by the canal have become a major component of the Mediterranean
ecosystem and have serious impacts on the ecology, endangering many local and
[endemic](/wiki/Endemism "Endemism") species. About 300 species from the Red
Sea have been identified in the Mediterranean, and there are probably others
yet unidentified. The Egyptian government's intent to enlarge the canal has
raised concerns from [marine biologists](/wiki/Marine_biologist "Marine
biologist"), fearing that this will worsen the invasion of Red Sea
species.[106]

Construction of the canal was preceded by cutting a small fresh-water canal
called [Sweet Water Canal](/wiki/Sweet_Water_Canal "Sweet Water Canal") from
[the Nile delta](/wiki/Nile_Delta "Nile Delta") along [Wadi
Tumilat](/wiki/Wadi_Tumilat "Wadi Tumilat") to the future canal, with a
southern branch to Suez and a northern branch to Port Said. Completed in 1863,
these brought fresh water to a previously arid area, initially for canal
construction, and subsequently facilitating growth of agriculture and
settlements along the canal.[107]

## Suez Canal Economic
Zone[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Suez_Canal&action=edit&section=29 "Edit
section: Suez Canal Economic Zone")]

The Suez Canal Economic Zone, sometimes shortened to the Suez Canal Zone,
describes the set of locations neighbouring the canal where customs rates have
been reduced to zero in order to attract investment. The zone comprises over
600km² within the governorates of [Port Said](/wiki/Port_Said_Governorate
"Port Said Governorate"), [Ismailia](/wiki/Ismailia_Governorate "Ismailia
Governorate") and [Suez](/wiki/Suez_Governorate "Suez Governorate"). Projects
in the zone are collectively described as the [Suez Canal Area Development
Project](/wiki/Suez_Canal_Area_Development_Project "Suez Canal Area
Development Project") (SCADP).[108][109]

The plan focuses on development of [East Port
Said](/wiki/East_Port_Said_Industrial_Zone "East Port Said Industrial Zone")
and the port of [Ain Sokhna](/wiki/Ain_Sokhna "Ain Sokhna"), and hopes to
extend to four more ports at West Port Said, El-Adabiya, [Arish](/wiki/Arish
"Arish") and [El Tor](/wiki/El_Tor,_Egypt "El Tor, Egypt").[110]

The zone incorporates the three "Qualifying Industrial Zones" at Port Said,
Ismailia and Suez, a 1996 American initiative to encourage economic ties
between Israel and its neighbours.[111]
